titleStmt.title: Inscription in honour of Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Arcadius, Honorius from Antinoupolis by Tatianus praet. praefect

availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

msIdentifier.idno: inv. 21783; displayed in the Museum garden

layout.p: The inscription is chiselled on a reused monument: it is located on the back of the base; on the front face there is an earlier inscription dedicated to Antinous, dating to 130/140 AD (Bernand 1984, pp. 57-62, nr 2).
layout.rs: Our inscription is complete and has 11 lines. The name of the awarder was deliberately erased (lines 6-7).

div.ab:
Τοὺς τῆς ὑφ’ ἡλίῳ γῆς αὐτοκρά
τορας καὶ τροπαιούχους δεσπότας
ἡμῶν, Οὐαλεντινιανόν, Θεοδόσιον,
Ἀρκάδιον, τοὺς αἰωνίους Αὐγούσ
τους, καὶ Φλάυιον Ὁνώριον, τὸν
ἐπιφανέστατον, Φλάυιος Εὐτόλμιος
Τατιανός, ὁ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος
τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραιτωρίου, τῇ συνήθει
καθοσιώσει ἀφιέρωσεν, ἐπὶ Φλαυίου
Σεπτιμίου Εὐτροπίου τοῦ λαμπροτάτου
ἡγεμόνος.

div.p: This edition follows the text edited by LSA and Bernand 1984.

app.note: ἀφοσιωσει: Wescher 1899 read this word as the future indicative active 3rd singular from ἀφοσιόω, which can be translated with “he will consecrate”.

div.p: “Agli imperatori della Terra sotto il sole, trionfanti, i nostri signori Valentinianus, Teodosius, Arcadius, perpetui Augusti, e Flavius Honorius, nobilissimo, il chiarissimo Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, prefetto del sacro praetorio, realizzò con la consueta devozione, quando era governatore (di Tebaide) il chiarissimo Flavius Septimius Eutropius.”

“To the emperors of the Earth under the sun, triumphant, our masters Valentinianus, Theodosius, Arcadius, the eternal Augusti, and Flavius Honorius, the most noble, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, of clarissimus rank, prefect of the sacred praetorium, set this up with the customary devotion, when Flavius Septimius Eutropius was governor (of Thebais) of clarissimus rank.”

“Aux empereurs de la Terre sous le soleil, triomphateurs, nos seigneurs Valentinianus, Theodosius, Arcadius, Augustes perpétuels, et Flavius Honorius, le très noble, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, clarissime préfet du prétoire sacré, a réalisé avec la dévotion habituelle, quand il était gouverneur clarissime Flavius Septimius Eutropius.”

The inscription is on a statue base in honour of Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Arcadius and Honorius emperors and it was found in the ancient city of Antinoupolis, today el Sheikh ‘Abadah in Egypt. Initially, the monument was brought to the Cairo Museum (nr. 9274) (Dittemberg in OGIS II) and then transferred to the Alexandria Museum (nr. 21783), in 1925. Today, it is displayed in the Museum garden (Bernand 1984, p. 57; LSA 876). Our inscription is on the back of a large statue base, the front face of which retains an earlier dedication to Antinous (130/40 AD) (Bernand 1984 pp. 57-62, nr. 2; Wescher 1866, pp. 150-153). Th. Kraus (1962, p. 131) pointed out that «on the top there are foot-holes of an over life-size bronze statue, which must belong to the first use, since they point towards the first-use side» (cf. U. Gehn, LSA 876).

The text is 11 lines long and has been deliberately erased on lines 6 and 7, where the awarder Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus (PLRE I, p. 876) was mentioned. He was a distinguished pagan, who held the eastern praetorian prefecture in 388-392 AD (see also PPRET 85, 88, 90), falling from power in 392 AD. He suffered damnatio memoriae and banishment to Lycia. He was rehabilitated posthumously by his grandson at Aphrodisias in Caria (PPRET 91). His whole career is recorded in ascending order of importance from praeses (ἡγεμών) to praefectus (ἔπαρχος) in a long inscription from Sidyma (see PPRET 87). During his prefecture, Tatianus was also involved in erecting honorary inscriptions on behalf of the imperial college (PPRET 82, 83, 84) in Aphrodisias (Caria) and in Side (Pamphylia) which is a ‘twin’ inscription of our Egyptian one (PPRET 85). Just as in our inscription the prefect uses the formula τῇ συνήθει καθοσιώσει, which probably alludes to pagan rites that accompanied the dedication and which must have been chosen by him, since it appears in Aphrodisias as well as in Egypt.
Since our base can only have supported one statue, it has must been one of a group of bases with similar dedications.

The inscription was set up during the mandate of the governor of the Thebais, Flavius Septimius Eutropius (PLRE I, p. 318), recorded as governor in a papyrus dated to 26th December 389 AD. Since his predecessor, Flavius Eutolmius Arsenius (PLRE I, p. 111), was in office in June 388 AD and his successor, Flavius Asclepiades Hesychius (PLRE I, p. 429), in September 390 AD, our inscription has to date to 388/390 AD.

div.p: ὁ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραιτωρίου
